message_1:
In modal logic, a proposition can be represented as a statement with possible worlds. Consider the proposition "It will rain tomorrow," which can be represented by the symbol p. Let M = {w1, w2, w3} be the set of three possible worlds.

Suppose that p is true in world w1, false in world w2, and true in world w3. Determine the truth value of the following formulas:

1. ◊p ∧ ¬p
2. ◊(p ∧ ¬p)
3. □p ∨ ¬□p

Note: ◊ denotes "possibly" and □ denotes "necessarily".
message_2:
1. ◊p ∧ ¬p

◊p means that p is possibly true, which means that there exists at least one world where p is true. Since p is true in worlds w1 and w3, ◊p is true. ¬p means that p is false. Since p is false in world w2, ¬p is true. Therefore, ◊p ∧ ¬p is true.

2. ◊(p ∧ ¬p)

This formula means that there is a possible world where p and ¬p are both true simultaneously. However, in our set of possible worlds, there is no such world where p is both true and false at the same time. Therefore, ◊(p ∧ ¬p) is false.

3. □p ∨ ¬□p

□p means that p is necessarily true, which means that p is true in all possible worlds. Since p is false in world w2, □p is false. ¬□p means that it is not the case that p is necessarily true, which is the same as saying that p is not true in all possible worlds. Since p is false in world w2, ¬□p is true. Therefore, □p ∨ ¬□p is true.
